title: Possible missing type inference in `iterator_try_reduce`
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
#![feature(iterator_try_reduce)]

fn fallible(check: usize) -> Result<usize, &'static str> {
    if check > 10 {
        Err("Too large")
    } else {
        Ok(check)
    }
}

fn repro() -> Option<usize> {
    [1, 2, 3]
        .into_iter()
        .try_reduce(|accum, item| {
            let num = fallible(item)?;
            Ok(accum + num)
        })
        .unwrap()
}

fn main() {
    let num = repro().unwrap();
    println!("{num:?}");
}
```

I expected to see this happen: The error type `E` for the `try_reduce` method should be inferable to be `&'static str`.

Instead, this happened: error[[E0282]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/error_codes/E0282.html): type annotations needed: cannot infer type of the type parameter `E` declared on the enum `Result`

I'm not sure if this is a bug, as maybe there is a good reason why the type cannot be inferred. However, given the `?` will return a `Err(&'static str)`, no other type could be `E`, so in principle it should be possible to infer it.
